Fig. 1 Comparison of methane oxidation activities of Pd/MFI (Si/Al=1000), Pd/Al2O3, and Pd/SiO2 catalysts. All catalysts contained 3 wt% Pd. The as-prepared catalysts after 500 ℃ air calcination are labeled as fresh; the aged ones were further treated at 700 ℃/40 h/10% H2O in air. Reaction conditions: 1120 ppm CH4, 65 ppm C2H6, 800 ppm CO, 9% O2, 10% H2O, 6% CO2, balanced with N2, GHSV of 100,000 ml/g/h [58]. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Methane conversion as a function of temperature on a series of fresh and aged 3 wt% Pd/MFI catalysts with different Si/Al ratios. Fresh catalysts were calcined at 500 ℃/2 h/air before testing; aged catalysts were pre-treated at 700 ℃/40 h/10% H2O in air before testing. Reaction conditions: 1120 ppm CH4, 65 ppm C2H6, 800 ppm CO, 9% O2, 10% H2O, 6% CO2, balanced with N2, GHSV 100,000 ml/g/h [58]. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 FTIR spectra of CO adsorbed on Pd/MFI (SiAl = 20) and Pd/MFI (SiAl = 000) samples [58]. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 FTIR spectra in the OH stretching vibration region for two sets of high silica MFI samples before and after PdPt addition [92]. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Comparison of the time-on-stream stability of PdPt/MFI (Si/Al=1000) vs PdPt/Al2O3 for methane oxidation in a feed that contained 0.5 ppm SO2 (when it was on). The catalysts were washcoated on monolith substrates with 1.64 g/L of Pd and 0.33 g/L of Pt. Testing conditions: 1000 ppm CH4, 25 ppm C2H6, 5 ppm C3H8, 1000 ppm CO, 12% O2, 500 ppm NO, 8% H2O, 5% CO2, 0 or 0.5 ppm SO2 (when it was on as indicated by the shaded areas), and balanced with N2, with a temperature at 580 ℃ [58]. Aged samples were treated at 650 ℃/50 h/10% H2O in air. Zeolite supported Pd catalysts for the complete oxidation of methane: A critical review Hai-Ying Chen a ⁎ 1 Jing Lu b Joseph M. Fedeyko b Agnes Raj c a Oak Ridge National Laboratory, 2360 Cherahala Blvd, Knoxville, TN 37932, USA Oak Ridge National Laboratory 2360 Cherahala Blvd Knoxville TN 37932 USA Oak Ridge National Laboratory, 2360 Cherahala Blvd, Knoxville, TN, 37932 b Johnson Matthey Inc., 436 Devon Park Dr, Wayne, PA 19087, USA Johnson Matthey Inc. 436 Devon Park Dr Wayne PA 19087 USA Johnson Matthey Inc., 436 Devon Park Dr, Wayne, PA, 19087 c Johnson Matthey Technology Center, Sonning Common, UK Johnson Matthey Technology Center Sonning Common UK Johnson Matthey Technology Center, Sonning Common, UK ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Orcid.org/0000-0003-4116-2607 This review summarizes the recent literature reports on the development of zeolite supported Pd catalysts for the complete oxidation of methane. In-depth analysis reveals that different types of zeolite framework structures, regardless of the dimensionality, pore opening structure, and channel size, have little influence on the methane oxidation activity or the on-stream stability of the supported Pd catalysts. In contrast, the Si/Al ratio of a zeolite support plays a critical role. Both the catalytic activity and the on-stream stability of a Pd/zeolite catalyst increase with the increase of the Si/Al ratio. Catalysts supported on siliceous zeolites consistently show excellent light-off activity and remarkable on-stream stability whether in a dry or wet feed. Silanol nest defect sites in a siliceous zeolite are proposed to be the anchoring sites promoting the formation and minimizing the sintering of finely dispersed Pd nanoparticles. Remaining challenges in overcoming the sulfur poisoning effect are discussed. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Methane oxidation Pd catalysts Zeolite support Siliceous zeolite PdO nanoparticles Silanol nest defect sites 1 Introduction Catalytic oxidation of methane is of great importance either for methane combustion as an energy source or for methane abatement from various exhaust streams, such as GNG engine exhausts, coal mine ventilation air, flare gas, and agricultural sources. Complete oxidation of methane to CO2 effectively reduces its environmental impact by more than 96% as the global warming potential of methane is about 28–36 times greater than that of CO2 over a 100-year scale [1]. Low temperature operation and long-term stability are two major design targets for catalyst development. Low operating temperatures are critical in minimizing the formation of secondary emissions, such as NOx, for methane combustion, or enabling systems to achieve low methane emission standards for methane abatement. A wide range of catalysts have been studied to promote the reaction, including both Platinum Group Metals (PGM) and earth-abundant metal oxides (non-PGM) catalysts. Many excellent review papers that summarize catalyst selection, catalyst properties, support effects, nature of the active sites, reaction kinetics, water inhibition and sulfur poisoning mechanisms, and the influence of operating conditions are available in the literature [2–10]. Of all the catalysts reported, PGM catalysts exhibit the highest intrinsic activity at low temperatures, capable of achieving near 100% methane conversion at temperatures below 600 ℃. In contrast, non-PGM catalysts are in general 3–5 orders of magnitude lower in reaction rates and require operation temperatures above 600 ℃ to reach 100% conversion. Despite the strong interest and substantial development effort over the past several decades for improved low-temperature methane oxidation catalysts, Al2O3 supported Pd-based catalysts remain the-state-of-the-art catalysts [9]. Although Pt is typically incorporated in commercial catalysts to enhance the thermal stability and sulfur tolerance, Pd is the major catalytic component. These catalysts, however, still suffer from water inhibition and sulfur poisoning effects. High PGM loadings (>5 wt%) and operation temperatures above 550 ℃ are necessary to maintain near 100% methane conversion in real-world applications [9]. Many alternative supports, such as ZrO2 [11–17], CeO2 [18–24], CeZrO2 mixed oxides [25–29], SnO2 [30–35], and zeolites (see references in Table 1) with various additives have been evaluated. Each type of support shows certain beneficial features; for example, ZrO2 supported catalysts display higher on-stream stability; CeO2, CeZrO2, or SnO2 supported catalysts exhibits lower light-off temperature; and zeolite supported catalysts demonstrate better tolerance to water inhibition. However, each of these catalysts also exhibits certain noticeable drawbacks and is overall inferior to Al2O3 supported reference catalysts. It is generally accepted that low temperature methane oxidation on Pd-based catalysts follows the Mars-van Krevelen redox mechanism [11,36–44]. CH4 molecules are first adsorbed on the surface of PdO nanoparticles and dissociate to adsorbed methyl (CH3-) and surface hydroxyl (Pd-OH) groups. Because of the strong C-H bonding energy (435 kJ/mol) and the symmetrical configuration of CH4 molecules, the initial H-abstraction is the rate limiting step. This reaction mechanism is consistent with the observation that the reactivity of a Pd catalyst depends on the particle sizes of PdO on the surface. With very small PdO particles, the Pd-O bonds might be too strong and therefore less active in activating the C-H bond in methane molecules. On the other hand, large PdO particles result in decrease of Pd dispersion, or the number of surface sites at a given Pd loading. Although the optimal PdO size is still under debate, it has been proposed that medium sized (~4 nm) PdO nanoparticles exhibit the highest TOF even though small particles (less than 1–2 nm) may provide early ignition [45,46]. Pd/Al2O3 catalysts are known to be severely inhibited and gradually deactivated by H2O. Formation of surface hydroxyl groups on the Al2O3 support and PdO sites are identified as the leading causes even though the fundamental deactivation mechanisms are not fully understood [2,47–57]. Nevertheless, this theory has inspired renewed interest in investigating zeolites, especially those with high silica content, as alternative supports because of their hydrophobic character. Recent studies demonstrate that Pd supported on high silica zeolites are noticeably more active and stable than Pd/Al2O3 in wet feed (see references in Table 1). Interestingly, when Pd is supported on a high surface area amorphous SiO2, the catalyst is much less active than the zeolite catalyst and deactivates almost completely after hydrothermal treatment at 700 ℃ [58] (see Fig. 1). It is worth mentioning that the SiO2 support used in the study by Lu et al. was not a totally hydrophobic SiO2. However, Araya et al. demonstrated that SiO2 with different degree of hydrophobicity had barely any influence on the catalytic behavior of the supported Pd catalysts for methane oxidation [59]. A simple conclusion one could draw here would be that the framework structures of the zeolite support play certain roles. However, as will be discussed extensively in Section 2 and Section 3, such activity and stability enhancement has been reported in a variety of zeolite materials with either 1D (dimensional), 2D, or 3D framework structures and with pore sizes ranging from small- (6-ring, ~0.38 nm), medium- (8-ring, ~0.53 nm), large- (12-ring, ~0.67 nm), to various mesopores (~3–7 nm), and there does not appear to be any correlations between the catalytic activity of the Pd/zeolite catalyst and the dimensionality/pore size of the zeolite support. Therefore, other features in high silica zeolites that contribute to such catalytic activity and stability improvement are worth an in-depth review. This paper will first summarize the recent literature reports of zeolite supported Pd catalysts for the complete oxidation of methane in an excess supply of oxygen, which include both methane combustion and lean exhaust methane emission control. Methane emission control under stoichiometric conditions is out of the scope of this review as the chemistry and the reaction mechanisms are totally different. Critical analysis will be provided in Sections 3–5 to correlate the catalytic activity and stability of the Pd/zeolite catalysts with the various chemical and physical properties of the zeolite supports. These include the roles of zeolite framework structures, silicon to aluminum ratio, and acid sites of the zeolite supports. Different types of Pd species, the related particle size distribution and location in the zeolite supports, and how these properties affect methane oxidation activity will also be examined. Discussions will be focusing on the fundamental questions about the nature of the active Pd sites and the associated anchoring sites of the zeolite supports. Finally, remaining challenges and perspectives for future development efforts will be presented. 2 Development of zeolite supported Pd catalysts for the complete oxidation of methane Table 1 summarizes most of the recent journal publications and a few selected patent applications that reported zeolite supported Pd catalysts for the complete oxidation of methane. The list groups the studies into several categories that will be discussed below in detail. Within each category, the studies are listed in the order of the publication year. 2.1 Early development work on zeolite supported Pd catalysts for methane oxidation Although evaluation of zeolite supported Pd catalysts for methane oxidation can be dated back earlier [60–62], Li and Armor were the first ones who directly compared this type of catalysts against a Pd/Al2O3 reference for methane oxidation [63]. Three zeolite framework structures (MFI, MOR, and FER) were evaluated in their work, all of which showed 70–80 ℃ lower light-off temperatures than a Pd/Al2O3 reference. Atomically dispersed Pd2+ ions at the exchange sites of the zeolite supports were attributed to be the active centers. Their results were soon confirmed by other research groups [64,65]. These studies also pointed out that the hydrothermal stability of the zeolite (with a low Si/Al ratio, <100) supported catalysts were relatively poor and required a significant improvement for practical use. Subsequently, in a series of studies by Niwa and coworkers [66–68], PdO agglomerates were identified to be more active than atomically dispersed Pd2+ ions in the zeolite supports although the nature of the PdO agglomerates was not fully discussed. It was also discovered that zeolites with a higher Si/Al ratio usually resulted in catalysts with higher methane oxidation activities and significantly improved water tolerance and on-stream stability. On several high silica zeolite (with the Si/Al ratio up to 500) supported Pd catalysts, they recorded stable methane conversion for 6 h in a feed that contained 10% H2O. In these early studies, all the zeolite catalysts were prepared by ion-exchange methods. Subsequent studies from Lu’s research group demonstrated that catalysts made by impregnation methods were more active, either in dry or wet feed, than those by ion-exchange [69,70]. In the studies published more recently, impregnation methods were more commonly used. 2.2 Evaluation of various zeolite support materials Soon, a wider range of microporous zeolites with various framework structures, ranging from 12-ring large-pore, 10-ring medium-pore, to 8-ring small-pore, were evaluated and reported to all exhibit improved methane oxidation activity and better water tolerance than Pd/Al2O3 reference catalysts [71–78]. In addition to aluminosilicate zeolites, silicoaluminophosphate (SAPO) molecular sieves (which will be generalized as zeolites thereafter in this paper) were also reported to be promising support materials [79]. Additionally, mesoporous zeolite materials, such as Al-MCM-41, MCM-41, SBA-15, and HMS, were also evaluated and reported to improve the methane oxidation activity and stability [80–87]. A Pd/SBA-15 catalyst with ZrO2 as a promoter reached 400 h of time-on-stream (TOS) stability in a dry feed [84]. The hydrophobic character of the SBA-15 support was attributed to be one of the major contributing factors to the outstanding on-stream stability. Noting that most of the mesoporous zeolites evaluated were pure silica in composition and all outperformed the aluminosilicate counterparts, the results clearly indicate that PdO nanoparticles, instead of atomically dispersed Pd2+ ions at the exchange sites, are the active centers. This topic will be discussed further in Section 4. Recognizing their hydrophobic nature, medium-pore TS-1 (MFI), TS-2 (MEL), and Silicalite-1 (MFI) zeolites were evaluated by a number of research groups [88–91]. All catalysts showed good methane oxidation activities and excellent stability. A Pd/TS-1 catalyst demonstrated 1900 h of TOS stability in a feed that contained 3.2% H2O at operating temperatures below 430 ℃, which is remarkable [88]. In a patent application by Chen et al., it was claimed that a wide range of zeolites with a Si/Al ratio no less than 750 (i.e. siliceous zeolites) could be used as supports for Pd-based methane oxidation catalysts to exhibit high activity and excellent water tolerance [92]. The long-term stability of a high silica MFI supported Pd catalysts was confirmed by Velin et al. [93]. In a recent study, however, Luo et al. reported an opposite trend [94]. They claimed that the methane oxidation activity of a series of Pd/MFI catalysts decreased with the increase of Si/Al ratio (ranging from 28 to ∞). It should be noted that the catalysts were prepared by a deposition-precipitation method with solutions of Pd salt (H2PdCl4) and NaOH being simultaneously added into the zeolite suspension while keeping the pH of the mixture above 8. This method effectively led to the deposition of PdO particles on the external surface of the zeolite support, as confirmed by their TEM characterization results. Analysis of the PdO particle size distribution revealed that the PdO particle size increased with the increase of the Si/Al ratio of the zeolite support. Therefore, it is more likely that different PdO particle sizes on the zeolite supports, rather than the different Si/Al ratios of the zeolites as the authors claimed, dictates the methane oxidation activity. This will be further discussed in Section 3. 2.3 Effects of promotors and roles of alkali metal ions Both the methane oxidation activity and the on-stream stability of Pd/zeolite catalysts could be further enhanced by incorporation of other components or metal ions to the aluminosilicates or siliceous zeolites. Promoters, such as CeO2, ZrO2, and TiO2 were reported to have significant positive effects [84,85,95–98]. The fundamental mechanisms of such promotion effects, however, were poorly understood. The trends observed with one type of zeolite support were inconsistent with what reported for other types of zeolites. In the early studies, most of the catalysts were prepared by ion-exchange methods. Those catalysts often contained Na+ ions either from the parent zeolite materials or through NaOH addition for pH adjustment during the ion-exchange step. Although the benefits of having Na+ ions were acknowledged in some of the early studies [65,66,71], systematic studies to understand the role of Na+ and other alkali metal ions were not carried out until much later [99–103]. Those follow-up studies not only confirmed the promotion effect of Na+ but also discovered that addition of alkali metal ions, especially in the step after Pd already being deposited onto the zeolite supports, could significantly enhance the stability of catalysts in wet feed. These newer results clearly contradicted with the earlier belief that highly dispersed Pd, which was stabilized by the Bronsted acid sites (or exchange sites) either as Pd2+ ions or as PdO small clusters, was the active sites for methane oxidation [63,65,69,99]. As Na+ ions usually neutralize the Bronsted acidity of the zeolite support, one would expect the opposite outcomes. This will be further discussed in Section 3. Here it must be pointed out that the promotion effects of alkali metal ions being reported in the literature were all with zeolites having a relatively low Si/Al ratio (Si/Al < 100). For siliceous zeolites, the presence of Na+ ions was reported to severely deactivate the catalysts [92]. In a most recent study, Chen et al. reported that the incorporation of Co2+ ions into low Pd loaded (0.5 wt%) BEA (Si/Al=13) samples significantly improved the methane oxidation activity [104]. They concluded that the presence of Co2+ ions led to the formation of PdO nanoparticles, instead of exchanged Pd2+ ions, which supports the theory that PdO nanoparticles are more active than ionic Pd to catalyze methane oxidation (see Section 3). 2.4 Effects of catalyst preparation methods for Pd addition A variety of Pd salts, many containing chlorine, were used in different studies for catalyst preparation, but no systematic studies were carried out to examine if or how different Pd salts would affect the activity and durability of the finished catalysts. Overall, it appeared that all Pd salts yielded catalysts with adequate methane oxidation activity. Gelin and Primet devoted a subsection in their review paper to caution readers about the poisoning effect of residual chlorine from Cl-containing Pd/Pt salts on silica- and alumina- supported Pd/Pt catalysts [2]. The significance of residual chlorine effects on the methane oxidation activity and the on-stream durability of zeolite supported Pd catalysts is yet to be investigated. Here, since there is no attempt to compare the catalytic performance from one study to another, we leave this question open and will not discuss the effects of different Pd salts (this excludes pre-formed Pd nanoparticles, which will be discussed further below). As discussed above, both ion-exchange and impregnation methods were studied for Pd addition onto zeolite supports. Other methods, such as deposition precipitation, template ion-exchange, and grafting were also explored [82,83,94,99,100,103]. All these preparation methods produced catalysts with reasonably comparable methane oxidation activities with the impregnation methods overall having slight performance advantages. Subsequent catalyst pretreatment after Pd addition was found to have noticeable impact on the activity and stability of the catalysts. Liu et al. reported that a glow discharge plasma treatment of the Pd impregnated zeolite catalysts before calcination lowered the light-off temperature and extended the TOS stability of the catalysts [81,105,106]. They proposed that the plasma treatment improved PdO dispersion and enhanced its interaction with the zeolite supports. Xiao et al. applied an ozone treatment step after ion-exchange to promote [Pd[NH3]4]2+ to anchor at the silanol defect sites of a Silicalite-1 support, minimizing Pd migration onto the external surfaces of the zeolite support [107]. In a US patent application, Tissler et al. claimed a method for the preparation of highly active and durable PdPt/zeolite catalysts by calcining the impregnated samples under an inert atmosphere [108]. More recently, Nguyen et al. found a pre-reduction step with H2 at 100 ℃ before calcination in an inert atmosphere was beneficial [109]. They observed that most of the Pd/Pt particles of their catalyst were located on the external surface of the supports. Incorporation of Pd directly during the zeolite synthesis step was also explored [110–113]. All samples exhibited good stability. Although Gao et al. believed that Pd existed as isolated cationic ions in their samples based on their high resolution TEM results, their conclusion is debatable [113]. A more widely accepted theory is that small PdO nanoparticles being encapsulated in the zeolite crystals are the active site and such encapsulation prevents Pd migration and sintering [110–112]. 2.5 Pd addition as Pd nanoparticles Guided by the theory that PdO nanoparticles are the active sites for methane oxidation, several studies were carried out to introduce Pd nanoparticles directly onto zeolites to investigate where the PdO particles are located and how they interact with the zeolite supports [114–116]. Directly adding preformed Pd nanoparticles onto a zeolite only resulted in weak adsorption of Pd particles on the external surfaces of the zeolite, therefore the resulting catalysts were not thermally durable. Subsequent thermal exposures at different temperatures led to different degrees of Pd sintering and catalyst deactivation [115]. To place Pd nanoparticles inside the matrix of microporous zeolite crystals, Losch et al. developed an approach by generating mesopores in the microporous zeolites [114]. Preformed colloidal Pd nanoparticles (3.2 nm in diameter in their work) were subsequently introduced into the mesopores. With such an approach, a series of samples with a wide range of zeolite framework structures and different Si/Al ratios were prepared. TEM analysis verified that no Pd particles lied on the external surface of the supports. When the catalysts were tested for methane oxidation, however, only two samples exhibited slightly improved light-off activity than a Pd/Al2O3 reference. One of the best zeolite catalysts did show good stability (8 h TOS) in the feed with 3% of water. The lower light-off activity of the zeolite catalysts was partially attributed to the negative effects of the amorphous SiO2 residue generated during the process of creating mesopores [114]. Using a Pd amine complex, Wang et al. successfully incorporated Pd uniformly into the Silicalite-1 matrix as nanoparticles (2.3 ± 0.3 nm in diameter) [116]. When tested for methane oxidation, the catalyst was noticeably more active than a reference catalyst prepared by the conventional impregnation method. More remarkable is that the new catalyst maintained stable methane conversion for 300 h in a feed with 4.5% H2O. The hydrophobic nature of Silicalite-1, the fine and uniform PdO nanoparticle size, and the confinement of the zeolite matrix were all considered as the contributing factors to the superior activity and stability of the catalyst. A recent paper by Cui et al. included a detailed reaction kinetic, spectroscopic, and microscopic study on a series of Pd/CHA catalysts with different Pd loadings and with Si/Al ratios varying from 6 to 36 [117]. Their results showed that three type of Pd species co-existed in the zeolite catalysts: atomically dispersed Pd2+ cations at the exchange sites of the zeolites; highly dispersed PdO nanoparticles inside the zeolite cages, and PdO nanoparticles on the external surfaces of the zeolites. They demonstrated that Pd2+ ions at the exchange sites were much less active for methane oxidation than the PdO nanoparticles either inside the cages or on the surfaces of the zeolite supports. They also discovered that the highly dispersed PdO nanoparticles inside the cages deactivated rapidly due to Pd redispersion under reaction conditions. Therefore, PdO nanoparticles on the external surfaces of the zeolite support were attributed to be the active sites for methane oxidation. They showed that the PdO nanoparticle had good thermal stability under methane oxidation reaction conditions with a wet feed (2.5% H2O). These finds are consistent with what most recently reported by Friberg et al. [77]. Finally, it is worth noting that formation of carbonaceous deposition on a Pd/MFI (Si/Al = 140) under methane oxidation reaction conditions was also identified as a cause of catalyst deactivation [118]. This observation, however, seems to be unique to the specific catalyst investigated. 3 Role of zeolite framework structures As listed in Table 1, a variety of zeolites with a wide range of framework structures were evaluated as the support of Pd catalysts for methane oxidation. Table 2 summarizes these framework structures together with the dimensionality, pore opening structure and dimensions, and the maximum diameter of a sphere that can fit inside the largest channel of the corresponding framework. The information for the microporous zeolites is obtained from the “Database of zeolite structures” maintained by the Structure Commission of the International Zeolite Association (IZA-SC) [119], whereas the information for the mesoporous zeolites is cited from the references as noted in the table. The order of the zeolite framework structures listed in Table 2 simply follows the order as their first appearance in Table 1. Attempts to correlate the physical properties of the zeolite frameworks to the methane oxidation activity of the supported Pd catalysts yielded no consistent relationships. For example, when analyses were based on the dimensionality of the zeolite structure, the T50, the temperature at which the methane conversion reaches 50%, of a 3D MFI supported catalyst was 20 ℃ lower than a 1D MOR sample based on the results by de Correa et al. [65], whereas the opposite trend was reported by Park et al. [73]. As another example, when the analyses were based on the pore sizes, the T50’s for a series of SAPO molecular sieves supported catalyst appeared to decrease with the increase of pore sizes from 8- to 10- and 12-ring according to the activity data reported by Nomura et al. [79], but the results published by Park et al. showed 10-ring TUN and STI were more active than 12-ring BEA and FAU [73]. Also, no drastic improvement in activity was observed on the various mesoporous zeolites supported catalysts. On the other hand, it is a consistent trend that amorphous SiO2 supports, even with surface areas comparable to or higher than some of the zeolite supports, always resulted in catalysts with inferior methane oxidation activity [58,68]. Therefore, we conclude that it is the short-range localized zeolite framework structure, rather than the long-range zeolite crystallite structure, that provides coordination to Pd active sites producing catalysts with high and stable methane oxidation activity. This will be further discussed in Section 4. 4 Effects of Si/Al ratio, acid sites, and the presence of alkaline metal counter ions The trend that the methane oxidation activity and stability of Pd/zeolite catalysts increase with increasing Si/Al ratio of the zeolite support has been observed consistently since the early studies in the 1990 s. This trend is clearly illustrated in Fig. 2, in which a set of 3 wt% Pd/MFI catalysts with the Si/Al ratios varying from 20, 100, 400, to 1000 were evaluated for methane oxidation [58]. With the fresh (as-prepared) catalysts, although the on-set temperature for the Si/Al= 100 sample is slightly higher than that for the Si/Al= 20 sample, the overall trend - higher Si/Al ratio correlates with higher methane oxidation activity - is clear. The remarkable advantage of the catalysts with a very high Si/Al ratio is the hydrothermal stability after a 700 ℃/40 h/10% H2O treatment. As shown in Fig. 2, the T50 for the Pd/MFI (Si/Al=1000) catalyst increase only by about 30 ℃ from the fresh to the aged samples, whereas the Pd/MFI (Si/Al = 20 or 100) catalyst is almost fully deactivated after aging. To investigate why the Si/Al ratio had such a drastic impact on the catalytic activity and stability of the Pd/MFI catalysts, Lu et al. compared the FTIR spectra of the Pd/MFI catalysts with the lowest and the highest Si/Al ratios after CO chemisorption at ambient temperature [58]. The results are duplicated in Fig. 3. Well-defined IR bands with the maxima located in the 2217–2108 cm-1 region are evident on the Pd/MFI (SiAl = 20) sample. These IR bands are indicative of the presence of atomically dispersed Pd ions located at various exchange sites of the MFI zeolite [120]. In contrast, only three broad IR bands centered at 2152 (with a shoulder at 2162 cm-1), 2108, and 1885 cm-1 are observed on the Pd/MFI (SiAl = 1000) sample. These bands can be attributed to CO adsorption on finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles [121,122]. The absence of atomically dispersed cationic Pd ions in the high silica MFI sample should not be a surprise as the sample has virtually no acid sites (or exchange sites) to host Pd ions. On the other hand, based on the broadness of the FTIR bands in the 2170–2070 cm-1 region of the low Si/Al sample, it is safe to draw the conclusion that the low Si/Al sample, in its fresh state, also contains finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles. The lack of thermal stability of the low Si/Al samples is not due to the lack of hydrothermal stability of the parent MFI zeolites. In separate studies, where these zeolites were evaluated as HC trap materials, all showed good hydrothermal stability even after 800 ℃ hydrothermal treatment [123]. Also, it is not due to the migration and sintering of atomically dispersed Pd ions either. In fact, in studies of Pd/zeolite catalysts as low-temperature NOx storage materials, a hydrothermal treatment of the as-prepared samples at temperatures around 700 ℃ was found to be beneficial in enhancing Pd redispersion, generating a higher population of atomically dispersed Pd ions [124–127]. On the contrary, we believe that the deactivation of the of low Si/Al samples after 700 ℃ hydrothermal treatment is largely due to the redispersion of finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles into cationic Pd ions following a “protonolysis” reaction pathway as proposed by Adelman and Sachtler [128]: (1) PdO + 2H+ = Pd2+ + H2O Migration of the finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles to the external surfaces of the zeolite support and formation of larger PdO nanoparticles during the hydrothermal treatment may also contribute to the catalyst deactivation, although we believe this is a secondary factor (this will be further discussed in the next section). Therefore, although Bronsted acid sites in a zeolite may facilitate Pd ion-exchange and even stabilize finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles in an as-prepared catalyst as proposed by several research groups [63,65,69,94,99,109,113], the presence of Bronsted acid sites in the catalyst would eventually result in poor stability of the catalyst under reaction conditions due to conversion of the PdO nanoparticles into Pd cations through “protonolysis” at the acid sites. This conclusion is supported by the literature results already discussed in Section 2. Incorporation of alkali metal ions during the Pd addition step or through post addition into the Pd-loaded zeolite samples displaces protons at the exchange sites, which effectively hinders the “protonolysis” reaction pathway discussed above, thereby improving the activity and stability of the catalysts. This theory nicely explains the promotion effects of alkali metals as mentioned in Section 2.3 above [100–103]. Alternative, occupying the exchange sites with other metal ions, such as Co2+, also reduces the probability of Pd ions reaching the exchange site and leads to the formation of PdO nanoparticles, resulting in catalysts with higher methane oxidation activity as reported by Luo et al. [104]. On the other hand, Pd2+cations at the exchange sites can be readily reduced to Pd metal, which agglomerates to metal clusters [127,129]. The Pd metal clusters, if small enough, will be converted to PdO nanoparticles under methane oxidation reaction conditions. Therefore, pre-reducing Pd/zeolite catalysts under mild condition or calcining the samples under inert atmosphere converts Pd2+ ions to PdO nanoparticles, resulting in catalysts with higher activity. This explains the results discussed in Section 2.4 [108,109]. Obviously, a more effective way to minimize or eliminate the “protonolysis” reaction pathway is to use zeolites with fewer or no Bronsted acid sites. This is exactly one of the development directions many research groups have already recognized [88–93]. A wide range of high silica or siliceous zeolites have been reported to yield catalysts with excellent methane oxidation activity and TOS durability. Another advantageous feature of high silica zeolites is their hydrophobic character that further minimizes the water inhibition effect. 5 Nature of active Pd sites and the associated anchoring sites In the literature, Pd species in a Pd/zeolite catalyst are generally categorized into three groups: (1) atomically dispersed Pd ions at the exchange sites of the zeolite framework; (2) finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles, and (3) large PdO nanoparticle agglomerates on the external surfaces of the zeolite. Pd ions at the exchange sites can be characterized and quantified by NO chemisorption methods [124]. Large PdO agglomerates with sizes above 3 nm can be readily identified by TEM although quantification can be challenging. Analytic methods for characterizing finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles (< 3 nm), especially in a Pd/zeolite sample that also contains large PdO particles (and atomically dispersed Pd ions for zeolites with a low Si/Al ratio) are lacking. CO chemisorption methods are disproportionally more sensitive to atomically dispersed Pd whereas XRD methods are strongly skewed by large Pd particles. High resolution TEM measurement is typically used to fill the gap. Because selection of sample regions for imaging analysis can be subjective, the reported particle size for the finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles that are believed to be highly active for methane oxidation on Pd/zeolite catalysts is in a wide range of 1–4 nm [46,58,83,86,101,103,110–112,114–117], which is generally in agreement with the results reported for Pd/Al2O3 catalysts [45]. Most of the TEM results in the literature also indicate that the finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles are uniformly distributed on zeolite supports and are distinctively different from the larger PdO nanoparticle agglomerates that sit on the external surface the zeolite crystals [58,117]. Clearly, PdO nanoparticles with a size of 1–4 nm cannot fit inside the cage or channel structures of any microporous zeolites as the maximum diameter of a sphere that can be included in the cages or channels of these zeolites is in the range of 0.6–1.1 nm (see Table 2). Even with mesoporous zeolites, these particles can barely fit in the pores. This brings up a question - where are these finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles located and what sites stabilize the nanoparticles and prevent them from sintering and forming large agglomerates? Several studies speculated that silanol nests in a zeolite might serve as anchoring sites for the finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles [83,86,91] but did not provide strong evidence to support the conclusion. In a patent application, Chen et al. compared two different high silica MFI zeolites with identical Si/Al ratio (both at 1060), BET surface area, and crystal size [92]. They noted that the major difference between the two zeolite materials was the amount of silanol groups, which could be identified by the OH stretching vibration bands of their FTIR spectra and quantified by K uptake measurement. Fig. 4 replicates the FTIR spectra reported by Chen et al. On the MFI sample with silanol nests, an intense and broad IR band centered at 3425 cm-1 together with two relatively smaller but sharp bands at 3695 and 3725 cm-1 are evident. The two sharp bands were assigned to OH stretching vibrations from isolated external silanol groups, whereas the broad band was attributed to hydrogen-bonded silanol groups where several silanol groups are in close proximity, i.e. silanol nest defect sites [130]. These IR bands are also present on the sample after PdPt addition although the intensity of the broad band from silanol nest defect sites decreases by roughly 10%. In contrast, the OH stretch region is almost flat for the MFI samples without silanol nest. K uptake measurement was applied to quantify the amount of silanol groups of the two parent zeolite samples [92]. The results together with the methane oxidation activity of the PdPt loaded catalysts are summarized in Table 3. The catalyst supported on the MFI zeolite with silanol nests is not only more active but also, more importantly, much more durable than the counterpart without silanol nests. The results by Chen et. al. lead us to conclude that silanol nest defect sites are where finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles are located. The confinement from the silanol nest defect sites further protects the PdO nanoparticles from sintering under methane oxidation reaction conditions or against hydrothermal aging, resulting in not only high catalytic activity but also stable on-stream durability and good high temperature stability. Because the confinement effect is from localized silanol defect sites, it is not surprising that the long-range zeolite framework structure or pore size has little influence on the formation and the stability of the finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles. As we discussed above, a wide range of zeolite supports with various framework structures and pore sizes (from micropores to mesopores) are all reported to be suitable supports for Pd as methane oxidation catalysts. Silanol nest defect sites are known to trap alkali metal ions. Once the sites are occupied by alkali metal ions, their interaction with PdO nanoparticles may become much weaker, if they interact at all. Indeed, Chen et al. reported that the presence of alkali metals during the catalyst preparation step for high silica zeolite supported Pd catalysts was detrimental [92]. This is another piece of supporting evidence that silanol nest defect sites serve as the anchoring sites for highly dispersed Pd nanoparticles. Finally, we have an explanation for the question of why amorphous SiO2 supported Pd catalysts consistently show lower methane oxidation activity and poor stability even though the supports have comparable surface area to high silica zeolites: the lack of the desirable silanol nest sites on an amorphous SiO2 appears to be the fundamental cause. 6 Remaining challenges While some zeolite supported Pd catalysts exhibit higher methane oxidation activity and improved on-stream durability compared to the state-of-the-art Pd/Al2O3 catalysts, this type of catalysts has not been widely adopted for commercial use. One of the major concerns is that the zeolite catalysts showed higher sensitivity to SO2 poisoning [58,75]. In real-world applications, sulfur is always present in natural gas stream or in the exhausts from natural gas engines or turbines even though its concentration can be very low. Resistance to sulfur poisoning remains a critical requirement. Lu et al. evaluated a high silica MFI (Si/Al=1000) supported PdPt catalyst against a commercial PdPt/Al2O3 catalyst in a feed that simulated the exhaust stream from a natural gas engine, which contained 0.5 ppm of SO2 [58]. As shown in Fig. 5, Lu et al. found that the zeolite supported catalyst was more susceptible to the instantaneous sulfur poisoning effect than the alumina catalyst. They rationalized the rapid deactivation of the zeolite catalyst in the sulfur-containing feed to be due to low affinity of the zeolite support with sulfur. As a result, sulfur directly bonded with the PGM component causing rapid loss of methane oxidation activity. Conversely, alumina is known to strongly interact with sulfur, thus trapping a considerable amount of sulfur and preventing it from directly poisoning the PGM component. As a result, the alumina catalyst appeared to be more sulfur tolerant at the beginning of the test. On the other hand, because the zeolite support did not trap much sulfur, the catalytic activity of the catalyst recovered quickly when sulfur was removed from the feed gas. In contrast, the recovery of the alumina catalyst was much slower. After about 20 h of the test with SO2 periodically turning on and off (1 h/1 h), the alumina catalyst reached the same methane conversion efficiency as the zeolite catalyst in the sulfur-containing feed although the methane conversion efficiency of the zeolite catalyst was much high in the sulfur-free feed. One could argue that the zeolite catalyst was superior to the alumina catalyst based on the overall results shown in Fig. 5. This points out a development opportunity for desulfation strategies by taking advantage of the non-sulfating nature of the zeolite support. 7 Conclusions This review systematically examined the results reported in the literature on the development of zeolite supported Pd catalysts for the complete oxidation of methane. It rationalized the empirical observations, some seemingly conflicting with each other, into a consistent theory that finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles located at the silanol nest defect sites of a zeolite support are the most active Pd species in catalyzing methane oxidation at low temperatures. The silanol nests provide confinement effects preventing finely dispersed PdO nanoparticles from migration and sintering, resulting in catalysts with much improved on-stream stability. Bronsted acid sites in a low Si/Al zeolite facilitate redispersion of PdO nanoparticles into atomically dispersed Pd ions at the exchange sites, which are inactive for low temperature methane oxidation. Therefore, Pd catalysts supported on zeolites with a high Si/Al ratio, or siliceous zeolites, consistently outperform zeolites with a low Si/Al ratio. Because silanol nest defect sites are originated from localized short-range disorder, the theory also explains the empirical observation that different types of zeolite framework structures have little influence on the catalytic performance and on-stream stability of the zeolites supported Pd catalysts. coredata.dc:description: This review summarizes the recent literature reports on the development of zeolite supported Pd catalysts for the complete oxidation of methane. In-depth analysis reveals that different types of zeolite framework structures, regardless of the dimensionality, pore opening structure, and channel size, have little influence on the methane oxidation activity or the on-stream stability of the supported Pd catalysts. In contrast, the Si/Al ratio of a zeolite support plays a critical role. Both the catalytic activity and the on-stream stability of a Pd/zeolite catalyst increase with the increase of the Si/Al ratio. Catalysts supported on siliceous zeolites consistently show excellent light-off activity and remarkable on-stream stability whether in a dry or wet feed. Silanol nest defect sites in a siliceous zeolite are proposed to be the anchoring sites promoting the formation and minimizing the sintering of finely dispersed Pd nanoparticles. Remaining challenges in overcoming the sulfur poisoning effect are discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Zeolite supported Pd catalysts for the complete oxidation of methane: A critical review
